awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Chasing the elusive syntrophic partners in direct interspecies electron transfer
awd_abstract_narration:
Anaerobic digestion is widely utilized worlwide to treat waste streams and convert them to biogas such as methane. Biogas fom anerobic digestion typically consists of 50-70% methane and thus needs to be treated to remove impurities including carbon dioxide and water vapor. To eliminate the need for addtional treatment and purification of biogas from existing anaerobic digesters, it is critical  to understand and quantify the metabolic pathways of the microbial consortial involved in biogas production. The overarching goal of this high-risk and high-reward EAGER project is to characterize and quantify the metabolic pathways that drive methane production during anaerobic digestion. To advance this goal, the Principal Investigator (PI) of this project proposes to carry out an integrated experimental research program to test the hypothesis that interspecies hydrogen transfer (IHT) and direct interspecies electron transfer (DIET) play an equally important role during biogas production by methanogenesis in electrically conductive environments. The successful completion of this EAGER project could provide new fundamental knowledge that could be leveraged to develop and implement new engineering reactor design and operational strategies to increase the methane content of biogas produced by anaerobic digestors. Further benefits to society will be achieved through student education and training including the mentoring of a doctoral student. 

Interspecies hydrogen transfer (IHT) and direct interspecies electron transfer (DIET) have been shown to contribute to biogas production by methanogenesis in electrically conductive environments. However, a fundamental understanding and quantification of the relative contributions of IHT and DIET to methanogenesis have remained elusive due to the lack of experimental techniques to directly measure the associated microbial metabolisms and activities. The overarching goal of this project is to address this knowledge gap. To advance this goal, the Principal Investigator (PI) of this project hypothesizes that IHT and DIET play an equally important role during biogas production by methanogenesis in electrically conductive environments. This hypothesis is based on the results of preliminary studies by the PI that identified a novel Geobacter species (Candidatus Geobacter eutrophica) that was abundant in anerobic reactors supplied with conductive granular activated carbon. The PI also found that the Candidatus Geobacter eutrophica bacteria actively expressed genes encoding proteins for both extracellular electron transfer and hydrogen metabolism. To test this new hypothesis, the PI proposes to carry out an integrated experimental research program structured around two specific aims: 1) enrich DIET-capable Geobacter bacteria and elucidate their extracellular electron transfer mechanisms (Specific Aim 1) and 2) enrich DIET-capable methanogens and characterize their extracellular electron uptake mechanisms (Specific Aim 2). To enrich the DIET-capable Geobacter and methanogen bacteria, the PI proposes to use electrochemical stimulation in bioelectrochemical systems with specially designed electrodes. By combining cyclic voltammetry with measurements of biogas production, ion chromatography, resonance Raman microscopy and omics (metagenomics and metatranscriptomics), the PI hopes to unravel the metabolic pathways responsible for DIET in both electron-donating and electron-accepting microbial partners. The successful  completion of this project has the potential for transformative impact through the generation of new fundamental knowledge to advance the development of new bioprocesses such as electro-methanogenesis that could convert waste streams to biogas with much higher methane yields than existing anerobic digestion reactors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: TEMPLE UNIVERSITY-OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

The goal of this project is to understand how microorganisms work together to produce biogas (a methane-rich renewable energy source) via a new microbial process known as direct interspecies electron transfer. In such a process , bacteria pass electrons directly to methanogens, and the latter uses the electrons to reduce carbon dioxide to methane. Biogas production via this process is more efficient than conventional processes and therefore more attractive in terms of energy recovery from waste.

To achive the goal and enhance biogas production, we used bioelectrochemical systems, a type of systems that allows microorganisms to grow in the presence of electric potentials (Figure 1). Granular activated carbon as a conductive material was added in bioelectrochemical systems to promote direct interspecies electron transfer, and the electrical potential was precisely controlled using a potentiostat. The cathodic potential was set at -0.4 V vs. standard hydrogen electrode to supply electrons to methanogens. The anodic potential was set at +0.8 V vs. standard hydrogen electrodeto take electrons from bacteria. This setup was expected to stimulate both methanogens and bacteria.

Our results showed enhanced biogas production by electrically stimulating direct interspecies electron transfer. As shown in Figure 2, more biogas was produced by applying a negative potential of -0.4 V to stimulate electron-accepting methanogens, and even more biogas was produced by applying both negative and positive potentials to stimulate electron-accepting methanogens and electron-donating bacteria at the same time.

The enhanced biogas produciton was further studied using advanced microbial community analysis. The microbial communities formed in the presence of potentials were structually different from those formed without potentials (Figure 3). One Methanobacterium population (methanogen) and two Geobacter populations (bacteria) were consistently observed with high abundance and activity in the communities (Figure 4). The Methanobacterium population’s 16S rRNA was upregulated by the cathodic potential (Figure 5). The Geobacter populations were also more active under alternating polarity but showed different preferences for the electrode potentials (Figure 5). 

Overall, the system and operation approach developed in this project successful enhanced biogas production and have important environmental implications. For example, after cultivation, activated carbon covered by biogas-producing microorganisms can be added directly in full-scale systems for immediate enhancement of biogas production. Stimulated by electrical ponteials, the microorganisms are expected to actively perform direct interspecies electron transfer without the need for continuous energy input. This is supported by the biogas production performance in the open circuit cycle, as well as the high abundance and active interactions of Geobacter and methanogens in those cycles. 

 

Broader Impacts

This project has promoted teaching, training and learning. Four high school students were involved in this project in the summers of 2022 and 2023. Two undergraduate students participated in this project in the 2021/2022 academic year. One Ph.D. student was supported by this project and will graduate in the fall of 2024. 

This project has broadened the participation of underrepresented groups. The four high school students involved in this project are from underrepresented communities. The two undergraduate students and one Ph.D. students are female.


Last Modified: 08/02/2024
Modified by: Heyang Yuan
